Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: The standard P2P steps are: create purchase requisition, approve it, issue a purchase order (PO), receive goods, receive the vendor invoice, match invoice to PO, release payment, and close the case.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 1001: The sequence looks normal. They created the requisition, approved it, issued PO, received goods, got the invoice, matched it, paid, and closed. No issues here.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Case 1002: They created the requisition, then immediately issued the PO without approval. Normally you can't issue a PO until the requisition is approved. That's a problem because it's an anomaly.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - NE
Text: In Case 1002, they paid before receiving goods. Typically, payment should be made after goods are received and the invoice is matched to the PO.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - NE
Text: Approving the purchase requisition after issuing the PO in Case 1002 is backward. Similarly, matching the invoice to the PO after releasing payment contradicts proper P2P controls. These are clear anomalies.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Case 1003: Release Payment on Feb 8 before receiving goods or invoice. Normally, payment should only happen after goods receipt and invoice matching.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - NE
Text: Case 1003: Payment was done before receiving goods or invoice and before matching any documentation. This violates standard controls and is an anomaly.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Case 1004: Receiving goods on Feb 6 before issuing a Purchase Order at 9:15 the same day. Normally goods are only received after issuing a PO, as the PO is what prompts the vendor to ship goods. This is an anomaly.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - IND
Text: Case 1004: It's possible that the PO was backdated or there was an error in the event log timestamps. However, even under this assumption, it raises questions about whether controls are being followed correctly.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - NE
Text: Case 1004: Receiving goods before issuing a PO contradicts standard P2P process controls and raises concerns about data integrity or procedural compliance. This is a significant issue.
